projects.title: Cobotic Applications - Mechatronic Support
projects.description:
AWL saw in Collaborative Robots an open opportunity in the market for industrial automation. I designed and help develop various collaborative applications for the Cobot Team as Mechanical/Mechatronics support. These applications were innovative in their nature, a few of them are listed below:

- Cobot Nut Welder
- Collaborative Welding Station
- Collaborative Welding Jig
- Carpet Gripping Arm
- Universal Magnetic/Pneumatic Gripper

projects.title: Airflow Optimization in Welding Cells - Solidworks Flow Simulation
projects.description:
AWL rolled out it's new product M-Line in 2019. "M" stood for modular. However nothing was farther from truth when it came to the air-flow system integrated in the new cells. For that still the old designs were being used without much consideration for air-flow optimization.

With the help of mechanical insight and Solidworks Flow Simulations, designed and developed improved designs which were:

- Twice as flow-efficient as the old ones
- Were cheaper through the use of off-shelf third party components
- Had a smaller space-claim in the welding cells

projects.title: Vision Handling Applications - Mechanical & Project Management Support
projects.description: The rise of Amazon is a tribute to the fact that vision handling applications are selling like hot cake. Being part of an R&D team which had vision and handling as one of the top priorities, I developed several applications with success for the Vision & Handling team. That included not only mechanical support but also sharing my organizational and management skills by keeping in constant touch with the stakeholders and making sure the support is delivered with planned milestones and capacity considerations.

projects.title: Water Flow Calculation Tool
projects.description:
Pipe Flow Expert
Last December 2018, AWL’s fluid department came to R&D with a simple problem. How to make sure that only the optimum amount of cooling water is provided to components used during operation in cells.

Which problem needed solving, and what’s in it for the customer/AWL?
Often our cooling water was reported insufficient for the welding process as a result we started over-designing components to compensate for potential insufficiencies in the future. PFE offers numerical solution to this problem by calculating exactly how much water is needed in which cooling circuits. 

What’s in it for AWL’s employees?
AWL’s fluid engineers can now sleep easy at night knowing the components they chose are based on exact facts and is less dependent on guesswork/experience. Result: Happier employees.

What’s in it for AWL as a company?
1.	Reduced costs for AWL by not having to over-design the system and hence not choosing expensive components where a smaller and cheaper would have sufficed. Result: Lower material costs
2.	By limiting guesswork and trial & error approaches, AWL saves on valuable man-hours onsite as well as off-site.

What’s in it for the customers?
1.	Customers will get machines which are even more reliable in their welding processes.
2.	Optimal machine components will make sure lower spare-parts costs for the customers as well as lower operational costs by saving on extra energy costs.
Project approach
At first, the idea was to develop our own calculation software. During market research, however, we found in Pipe Flow Expert (PFE) the perfect software catering to our needs. Thoroughly tested and studied by R&D, PFE is now handed-over to the Fluid department for use in regular projects.

Result 
 
Just through an investment of less than a 1000 euro’s per year, AWL can potentially save tens of thousands of euros on extra costs, have higher employee happiness index and more satisfied clients.

projects.title: Autonomous Mobile Robot Network - Design, Development & Implementation
projects.description:
AWL saw autonomous mobile robots as one of the key steps towards industry 4.0 and what better way to show off your expertise in that field by than to implement a AMR network for internal logistics. 
I was part of multiple phases of the project, including:
- Brainstorming and concept generation
- Concept engineering
- Concept testing and selection
- Detailed 3D engineering model
- Mechatronics components selection and procurement
- Development and assembly
- System testing and optimization through feedback

projects.title: In-project Support - Solidworks Flow Simulation
projects.description:
AWL's client was not convinced of the weld spatter removal capacity of the design. The project was destined to get delayed because of this bone of contention. Luckily computer simulations of the designed models came to the rescue. The results came out positive and were shared with the client who gave the green-light for the project.
In this project were demonstrated:
- Learning-on-the-job skills (Flow Simulation was new to me)
- Dedication to the cause (Under time pressure, some simulations were to be setup at 2 AM in the morning to save time)

projects.title: Futuristic Vision - Fully Automated Factory
projects.description:
AWL was 25 years old and it wanted to expand it's vision. It was decided that for the yearly "Tech-Days" the grand ideas for the factory of the future will be presented. 
As the lead in that project, after months of hard-work, a 2 minute video was scripted, modeled, animated, and presented to the clients.
The process included:
- Arranging and conducting brainstorm sessions for ideas
- Regular update and feedback meetings with the stakeholders
- Rigorous critique and dynamic implementation after each iteration

projects.title: Product Range Improvement & Expansion: Semiautomatic Filling & Sewing Machine (Potatoes)
projects.description:
Making existing SAS compatible with the American consumer market by modifying the module to incorporate additional features such as:
- Capability to handle bags of multiple sizes while minimizing downtime
- Making the machine robuster by including option to overhaul it at almost twice the speed for smaller bags
- Keeping the costs of engineering new components for the modified machine as low as possible by introducing multi-functionality for existing and new parts

projects.title: Standardization: Existing products, add-ons, construction-methodologies

- Streamlining development phases ensuring minimal repetitivity
How:

- Automation-oriented model setup using VBA in Autodesk Inventor

o	Reducing weight in combination with efficient distribution
o	Reducing development costs

profile_positions.description: If there is one thing that this pandemic has taught is, it is that there can no longer be physical barriers stopping companies from hiring the talent and skillset that they need no matter if its situated thousands of miles away. The remaining barrier is that of the mind! We at OOI are hell-bent to prove that this is the best way to get the job done with the least amount of resources while producing the best result by hiring offshore talent that is ready to delve into the most challenging problems your company has to offer.
